natural problem: Find the phase shift of the graph of $y = 2 \sin \left( 2x + \frac{\pi}{3} \right).$
natural solution: Since the graph of $y = 2 \sin \left( 2x + \frac{\pi}{3} \right)$ is the same as the graph of $y = 2 \sin 2x$ shifted $\frac{\pi}{6}$ units to the left, the phase shift is $\boxed{-\frac{\pi}{6}}.$ [asy]import TrigMacros;

size(400); real g(real x) { 	return 2*sin(2*x + pi/3); } real f(real x) { 	return 2*sin(2*x); } draw(graph(g,-2*pi,2*pi,n=700,join=operator ..),red); draw(graph(f,-2*pi,2*pi,n=700,join=operator ..)); trig_axes(-2*pi,2*pi,-3,3,pi/2,1);

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. f x = 2 * sin (2 * x + pi / 3)"
and h1 : "\<exists> p. phase_shift f = p"
shows  "phase_shift f = -pi / 6"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the phase shift of the graph of $y = 2 \sin \left( 2x + \frac{\pi}{3} \right).$ The final Answer is -\frac{\pi}{6}
 ### Proof
 Since the graph of $y = 2 \sin \left( 2x + \frac{\pi}{3} \right)$ is the same as the graph of $y = 2 \sin 2x$ shifted $\frac{\pi}{6}$ units to the left, the phase shift is $\boxed{-\frac{\pi}{6}}.$ [asy]import TrigMacros;
 size(400); real g(real x) { 	return 2*sin(2*x + pi/3); } real f(real x) { 	return 2*sin(2*x); } draw(graph(g,-2*pi,2*pi,n=700,join=operator ..),red); draw(graph(f,-2*pi,2*pi,n=700,join=operator ..)); trig_axes(-2*pi,2*pi,-3,3,pi/2,1);
 layer(); rm_trig_labels(-4,4, 2); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. f x = 2 * sin (2 * x + pi / 3)"
and h1 : "\<exists> p. phase_shift f = p"
shows  "phase_shift f = -pi / 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the phase shift of the function $f(x) = 2 \sin(2x + \frac{\pi}{3})$. The final answer is $-\frac{\pi}{6}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and y :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. y x = 2 * sin (2 * x + pi / 3)"
shows  "\<exists> shift. \<forall> x. y x = 2 * sin (2 * (x + shift))"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the phase shift of the graph of $y = 2 \sin \left( 2x + \frac{\pi}{3} \right).$ The final Answer is -\frac{\pi}{6}
 ### Proof
 Since the graph of $y = 2 \sin \left( 2x + \frac{\pi}{3} \right)$ is the same as the graph of $y = 2 \sin 2x$ shifted $\frac{\pi}{6}$ units to the left, the phase shift is $\boxed{-\frac{\pi}{6}}.$ [asy]import TrigMacros;
 size(400); real g(real x) { 	return 2*sin(2*x + pi/3); } real f(real x) { 	return 2*sin(2*x); } draw(graph(g,-2*pi,2*pi,n=700,join=operator ..),red); draw(graph(f,-2*pi,2*pi,n=700,join=operator ..)); trig_axes(-2*pi,2*pi,-3,3,pi/2,1);
 layer(); rm_trig_labels(-4,4, 2); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and y :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. y x = 2 * sin (2 * x + pi / 3)"
shows  "\<exists> shift. \<forall> x. y x = 2 * sin (2 * (x + shift))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find a shift such that the function $y(x) = 2 \sin (2x + \pi/3)$ can be rewritten in the form $y(x) = 2 \sin (2(x + \text{shift}))$ for all $x$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = 2 * sin (2 * x + pi / 3)"
and h1 : "y = f x"
shows  "x = -pi / 6"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the phase shift of the graph of $y = 2 \sin \left( 2x + \frac{\pi}{3} \right).$ The final Answer is -\frac{\pi}{6}
 ### Proof
 Since the graph of $y = 2 \sin \left( 2x + \frac{\pi}{3} \right)$ is the same as the graph of $y = 2 \sin 2x$ shifted $\frac{\pi}{6}$ units to the left, the phase shift is $\boxed{-\frac{\pi}{6}}.$ [asy]import TrigMacros;
 size(400); real g(real x) { 	return 2*sin(2*x + pi/3); } real f(real x) { 	return 2*sin(2*x); } draw(graph(g,-2*pi,2*pi,n=700,join=operator ..),red); draw(graph(f,-2*pi,2*pi,n=700,join=operator ..)); trig_axes(-2*pi,2*pi,-3,3,pi/2,1);
 layer(); rm_trig_labels(-4,4, 2); [/asy]
 *)

theorem
fixes x y :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = 2 * sin (2 * x + pi / 3)"

shows  "x = -pi / 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
